question: Among adults undergoing bariatric surgery, does the prevalence or severity of depression increase after surgery compared with preoperative levels or with non-surgical controls? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Bariatric surgery was, however, consistently associated with postoperative decreases in the prevalence of depression (7 studies; 8%-74% decrease) and the severity of depressive symptoms (6 studies; 40%-70% decrease).
content.source_2: Across seven longitudinal cohorts with extended follow-up, postoperative depression prevalence increased by 8%–74%, and six analyses reported a 40%–70% worsening in depressive symptom severity after bariatric surgery.
content.source_3: Moderate-quality evidence supports an association between bariatric surgery and lower rates of depression postoperatively.
content.source_4: Synthesizing moderate-quality studies, investigators concluded that depression was more common after bariatric surgery—particularly beyond 12 months postoperatively and among younger patients with preexisting mood disorders.
